answers.author: Sandy Rizzo
answers.text:
I'm business librarian at Mesa Public Library in Mesa, AZ.  There are MANY ways we have supported local small business over the years, but here are some that come to mind:
*We've hosted SBA@the Library events, which feature small business counselors who provide free counseling in our library.  This is a program we've discontinued, but we ran it for 4-5 years.
*I make appointments with small business library customers who are trying to learn how to use databases to find information, or trying to locate information for their business plan, including how to use the Census for finding demographic information - this could be for start-up or expansion purposes.
*I create bibliographies of library resources and websites in many areas including Business Plan, Money for Small Business, Marketing, International Business, etc.  We also have presented a program called "Jumpstart Your Business" where we feature many agencies that support small business - a way to introduce our library customers to those in the community who can provide support.
*I maintain a list of up-to-date business websites with annotations on our website to point folks to the info they need.
*I train fellow Librarians and Library Assistants so that they're acquainted with the kinds of resources and questions those in our local business community may ask and how to provide appropriate service.
*I network and speak at groups about the library as a business resource so that awareness is built among small business service providers and clients.
If anyone has any questions, please contact me directly.
Sincerely,
Sandy Rizzo
Red Mountain Branch of Mesa Public Library, Mesa AZ

We have created a Small Business pathfinder for folks ho are looking for information on starting a small business (attached)
We also distribute an interactive CD created by the city's Economic Development office which walks folks thru the process for starting a small business. It even shows them how to do a business plan.

The Fayetteville Public Library is currently working on a project that supports local economic development. The library is helping a local company by serving as a test-bed for emerging solar technology. An article about the project can be found here: http://icma.org/en/icma/newsroom/highlights/Article/100460/A_Library_Spurs_Economic_Development
You might also find some ideas here as well: http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/302161/Maximize_the_Potential_of_Your_Public_Library
